title: Lawrence Lessig
text:
Lester Lawrence Lessig III (born June 3, 1961) is an American academic, attorney, and <a href="political%20activist">political activist</a>. He is the Roy L. Furman Professor of Law at <a href="Harvard%20Law%20School">Harvard Law School</a> and the former director of the <a href="Edmond%20J.%20Safra%20Center%20for%20Ethics">Edmond J. Safra Center for Ethics</a> at <a href="Harvard%20University">Harvard University</a>. Lessig was a <a href="Lawrence%20Lessig%20presidential%20campaign%2C%202016">candidate</a> for the <a href="Democratic%20Party%20%28United%20States%29">Democratic Party</a>'s nomination for <a href="president%20of%20the%20United%20States">president of the United States</a> in the <a href="2016%20United%20States%20presidential%20election">2016 U.S. presidential election</a> but withdrew before the primaries.
Lessig is a proponent of reduced legal restrictions on <a href="copyright">copyright</a>, <a href="trademark">trademark</a>, and <a href="radio%20frequency">radio frequency</a> spectrum, particularly in technology applications. In 2001, he founded <a href="Creative%20Commons">Creative Commons</a>, a non-profit organization devoted to expanding the range of creative works available for others to build upon and to share legally. Prior to his most recent appointment at Harvard, he was a professor of law at <a href="Stanford%20Law%20School">Stanford Law School</a>, where he founded the <a href="Stanford%20Center%20for%20Internet%20and%20Society">Center for Internet and Society</a>, and at the <a href="University%20of%20Chicago">University of Chicago</a>. He is a former board member of the <a href="Free%20Software%20Foundation">Free Software Foundation</a> and <a href="Software%20Freedom%20Law%20Center">Software Freedom Law Center</a>; the Washington, D.C. lobbying groups <a href="Public%20Knowledge">Public Knowledge</a> and <a href="Free%20Press%20%28organization%29">Free Press</a>; and the <a href="Electronic%20Frontier%20Foundation">Electronic Frontier Foundation</a>. He was elected to the <a href="American%20Philosophical%20Society">American Philosophical Society</a> in 2007.
As a political activist, Lessig has called for state-based activism to promote substantive reform of government with a <a href="Second%20Constitutional%20Convention%20of%20the%20United%20States">Second Constitutional Convention</a>. In May 2014, he launched a crowd-funded <a href="political%20action%20committee">political action committee</a> which he termed <a href="Mayday%20PAC">Mayday PAC</a> with the purpose of electing candidates to <a href="United%20States%20Congress">Congress</a> who would pass <a href="Campaign%20finance%20reform%20in%20the%20United%20States">campaign finance reform</a>. Lessig is also the co-founder of <a href="Rootstrikers">Rootstrikers</a>, and is on the boards of <a href="MapLight">MapLight</a> and <a href="Represent.Us">Represent.Us</a>. He serves on the advisory boards of the "Democracy Café" and the <a href="Sunlight%20Foundation">Sunlight Foundation</a>.
In August 2015, Lessig announced that he was exploring a possible candidacy for President of the United States, promising to run if his exploratory committee raised $1 million by <a href="Labor%20Day">Labor Day</a>. After accomplishing this, on September 6, 2015, Lessig announced that he was entering the race <a href="Lawrence%20Lessig%20presidential%20campaign%2C%202016">to become a candidate</a> for the 2016 <a href="Democratic%20Party%20%28United%20States%29">Democratic Party</a>'s <a href="Democratic%20Party%20presidential%20candidates%2C%202016">presidential nomination</a>. Lessig described his candidacy as a referendum on <a href="Campaign%20finance%20reform%20in%20the%20United%20States">campaign finance reform</a> and <a href="electoral%20reform">electoral reform</a> legislation. He stated that, if elected, he would serve a full term as president with his proposed reforms as his legislative priorities. He ended his campaign in November 2015, citing rule changes from the Democratic Party that precluded him from appearing in the televised debates.
Academic career.
Lessig earned a <a href="Bachelor%20of%20Arts">B.A.</a> degree in economics and a <a href="Bachelor%20of%20Science">B.S.</a> degree in management (<a href="Wharton%20School">Wharton School</a>) from the <a href="University%20of%20Pennsylvania">University of Pennsylvania</a>, an <a href="Master%20of%20Arts%20%28Oxbridge%20and%20Dublin%29">M.A.</a> degree in <a href="philosophy">philosophy</a> from the <a href="University%20of%20Cambridge">University of Cambridge</a> (<a href="Trinity%20College%2C%20Cambridge">Trinity</a>) in England, and a <a href="Juris%20Doctor">J.D.</a> degree from <a href="Yale%20Law%20School">Yale Law School</a> in 1989. After graduating from law school, he <a href="Law%20clerk">clerked</a> for a year for Judge <a href="Richard%20Posner">Richard Posner</a>, at the <a href="United%20States%20Court%20of%20Appeals%20for%20the%20Seventh%20Circuit">7th Circuit Court of Appeals</a> in <a href="Chicago">Chicago</a>, <a href="Illinois">Illinois</a>, and another year for Justice <a href="Antonin%20Scalia">Antonin Scalia</a> at the <a href="Supreme%20Court%20of%20the%20United%20States">Supreme Court</a>.
Lessig started his academic career at the <a href="University%20of%20Chicago%20Law%20School">University of Chicago Law School</a>, where he was professor from 1991 to 1997. As co-director of the Center for the Study of Constitutionalism in Eastern Europe there, he helped the newly independent <a href="Georgia%20%28country%29">Republic of Georgia</a> draft a constitution. From 1997 to 2000, he was at <a href="Harvard%20Law%20School">Harvard Law School</a>, holding for a year the chair of Berkman Professor of Law, affiliated with the <a href="Berkman%20Klein%20Center%20for%20Internet%20%26amp%3B%20Society">Berkman Klein Center for Internet & Society</a>. He subsequently joined <a href="Stanford%20Law%20School">Stanford Law School</a>, where he established the school's <a href="Stanford%20Center%20for%20Internet%20and%20Society">Center for Internet and Society</a>.
Lessig returned to Harvard in July 2009 as professor and director of the Edmond J. Safra Center for Ethics. In 2013, Lessig was appointed as the Roy L. Furman Professor of Law and Leadership; his chair lecture was titled "Aaron's Laws: Law and Justice in a Digital Age."
In popular culture.
Lessig was portrayed by <a href="Christopher%20Lloyd">Christopher Lloyd</a> in "<a href="The%20Wake%20Up%20Call">The Wake Up Call</a>", during season 6 of "<a href="The%20West%20Wing">The West Wing</a>".
Political background.
Lessig has been politically <a href="Liberalism%20in%20the%20United%20States">liberal</a> since studying philosophy at Cambridge in the mid-1980s. By the late 1980s, two influential <a href="Conservatism">conservative</a> judges, Judge <a href="Richard%20Posner">Richard Posner</a> and Justice <a href="Antonin%20Scalia">Antonin Scalia</a>, selected him to serve as a <a href="law%20clerk">law clerk</a>, choosing him because they considered him brilliant rather than for his ideology and effectively making him the "token liberal" on their staffs. Posner would later call him "the most distinguished law professor of his generation."
Lessig has emphasized in interviews that his philosophy experience at <a href="University%20of%20Cambridge">Cambridge</a> radically changed his values and career path. Previously, he had held strong conservative or <a href="libertarianism">libertarian</a> political views, desired a career in business, was a highly active member of <a href="Teenage%20Republicans">Teenage Republicans</a>, served as the youth governor for Pennsylvania through the <a href="YMCA%20Youth%20and%20Government">YMCA Youth and Government</a> program in 1978, and almost pursued a <a href="Republican%20Party%20%28United%20States%29">Republican</a> political career.
What was intended to be a year abroad at Cambridge convinced him instead to stay another two years to complete an undergraduate degree in philosophy and develop his changed political values. During this time, he also traveled in the <a href="Eastern%20Bloc">Eastern Bloc</a>, where he acquired a lifelong interest in <a href="Eastern%20Europe">Eastern Europe</a>an law and politics.
Lessig remains skeptical of government intervention but favors some regulation, calling himself "a constitutionalist." On one occasion, Lessig also commended the <a href="John%20McCain">John McCain</a> campaign for discussing <a href="fair%20use">fair use</a> rights in a letter to <a href="YouTube">YouTube</a> where it took issue with YouTube for indulging overreaching copyright claims leading to the removal of various campaign videos.
Internet and computer activism.
"Code is law".
In <a href="computer%20science">computer science</a>, "code" typically refers to the text of a computer program (the <a href="source%20code">source code</a>). In law, "code" can refer to the texts that constitute <a href="statutory%20law">statutory law</a>. In his 1999 book "<a href="Code%20and%20Other%20Laws%20of%20Cyberspace">Code and Other Laws of Cyberspace</a>", Lessig explores the ways in which code in both senses can be instruments for <a href="social%20control">social control</a>, leading to his dictum that "Code is law." Lessig later updated his work in order to keep up with the prevailing views of the time and released the book as "" in December 2006.
Remix culture.
Lessig has been a proponent of the <a href="remix%20culture">remix culture</a> since the early 2000s. In his 2008 book <a href="Remix%20%28book%29">"Remix"</a> he presents this as a desirable cultural practice distinct from piracy. Lessig further articulates remix culture as intrinsic to technology and the Internet. Remix culture is therefore an amalgam of practice, creativity, "read/write" culture and the hybrid economy.
According to Lessig, the problem with the remix comes when it is at odds with stringent US copyright law. He has compared this to the failure of <a href="Prohibition">Prohibition</a>, both in its ineffectiveness and in its tendency to normalize criminal behavior. Instead he proposes more lenient licensing, namely <a href="Creative%20Commons%20license">Creative Commons license</a>s, as a remedy to maintain "rule of law" while combating plagiarism.
Free culture.
On March 28, 2004 Lessig was elected to the FSF's board of directors. He proposed the concept of "<a href="Free-culture%20movement">free culture</a>". He also supports <a href="free%20and%20open-source%20software">free and open-source software</a> and <a href="open%20spectrum">open spectrum</a>. At his free culture keynote at the <a href="O%27Reilly%20Open%20Source%20Convention">O'Reilly Open Source Convention</a> 2002, a few minutes of his speech was about <a href="software%20patent">software patent</a>s, which he views as a rising threat to <a href="free%20software">free software</a>, <a href="open%20source%20software">open source software</a> and innovation.
In March 2006, Lessig joined the board of advisors of the <a href="Digital%20Universe">Digital Universe</a> project. A few months later, Lessig gave a talk on the ethics of the Free Culture Movement at the 2006 <a href="Wikimania">Wikimania</a> conference. In December 2006, his lecture " On Free, and the Differences between Culture and Code" was one of the highlights at <a href="Chaos%20Communication%20Congress">23C3 "Who can you trust?"</a>.
Lessig claimed in 2009 that, because 70% of young people obtain digital information from illegal sources, the law should be changed.
In a foreword to the <a href="Freesouls">Freesouls</a> book project, Lessig makes an argument in favor of amateur artists in the world of digital technologies: "there is a different class of amateur creators that digital technologies have ... enabled, and a different kind of creativity has emerged as a consequence."
Lessig is also a well-known critic of <a href="copyright%20term">copyright term</a> extensions.
Net neutrality.
Lessig has long been known to be a supporter of <a href="net%20neutrality">net neutrality</a>. In 2006, he testified before the US Senate that he believed Congress should ratify <a href="Michael%20Powell%20%28attorney%29">Michael Powell</a>'s four Internet freedoms and add a restriction to access-tiering, i.e. he does not believe content providers should be charged different amounts. The reason is that the Internet, under the neutral end-to-end design is an invaluable platform for innovation, and the economic benefit of innovation would be threatened if large corporations could purchase faster service to the detriment of newer companies with less capital. However, Lessig has supported the idea of allowing ISPs to give consumers the option of different tiers of service at different prices. He was reported on CBC News as saying that he has always been in favour of allowing internet providers to charge differently for consumer access at different speeds. He said, "Now, no doubt, my position might be wrong. Some friends in the network neutrality movement as well as some scholars believe it is wrong—that it doesn't go far enough. But the suggestion that the position is 'recent' is baseless. If I'm wrong, I've always been wrong."
Legislative reform.
Despite presenting an anti-regulatory standpoint in many fora, Lessig still sees the need for legislative enforcement of copyright. He has called for limiting copyright terms for creative professionals to five years, but believes that creative professionals' work, many of them independent, would become more easily and quickly available if bureaucratic procedure were introduced to renew trademarks for up to 75 years after this five-year term.
Lessig has repeatedly taken a stance that privatization through legislation like that seen in the 1980s in the UK with British Telecommunications is not the best way to help the Internet grow. He said, "When government disappears, it's not as if paradise will take its place. When governments are gone, other interests will take their place," "My claim is that we should focus on the values of liberty. If there is not government to insist on those values, then who?" "The single unifying force should be that we govern ourselves."
Legal challenges.
From 1999 to 2002, Lessig represented a high-profile challenge to the <a href="Sonny%20Bono%20Copyright%20Term%20Extension%20Act">Sonny Bono Copyright Term Extension Act</a>. Working with the <a href="Berkman%20Center%20for%20Internet%20and%20Society">Berkman Center for Internet and Society</a>, Lessig led the team representing the plaintiff in "<a href="Eldred%20v.%20Ashcroft">Eldred v. Ashcroft</a>". The plaintiff in the case was joined by a group of publishers who frequently published work in the <a href="Public%20domain%20in%20the%20United%20States">public domain</a> and a large number of "<a href="Amicus%20curiae">amici</a>" including the <a href="Free%20Software%20Foundation">Free Software Foundation</a>, the <a href="American%20Association%20of%20Law%20Libraries">American Association of Law Libraries</a>, the <a href="Bureau%20of%20National%20Affairs">Bureau of National Affairs</a>, and the <a href="College%20Art%20Association">College Art Association</a>.
In March 2003, Lessig acknowledged severe disappointment with his Supreme Court defeat in the Eldred copyright-extension case, where he unsuccessfully tried to convince Chief Justice William Rehnquist, who had sympathies for de-regulation, to back his "market-based" approach to intellectual property regulation.
In August 2013, Lawrence Lessig brought suit against Liberation Music PTY Ltd., after Liberation issued a takedown notice of one of Lessig's lectures on YouTube which had used the song "<a href="Lisztomania%20%28song%29">Lisztomania</a>" by the band <a href="Phoenix%20%28band%29">Phoenix</a>, whom Liberation Music represents. Lessig sought damages under section 512(f) of the <a href="Digital%20Millennium%20Copyright%20Act">Digital Millennium Copyright Act</a>, which holds parties liable for misrepresentations of infringement or removal of material. Lessig was represented by the <a href="Electronic%20Frontier%20Foundation">Electronic Frontier Foundation</a> and <a href="Jones%20Day">Jones Day</a>. In February 2014, the case ended with a settlement in which Liberation Music admitted wrongdoing in issuing the takedown notice, issued an apology, and paid a confidential sum in compensation.
"Killswitch".
In October 2014, "Killswitch", a film featuring Lawrence Lessig, as well as <a href="Aaron%20Swartz">Aaron Swartz</a>, <a href="Tim%20Wu">Tim Wu</a>, and <a href="Edward%20Snowden">Edward Snowden</a> received its World Premiere at the <a href="Woodstock%20Film%20Festival">Woodstock Film Festival</a>, where it won the award for Best Editing. In the film, Lessig frames the story of two young hacktivists, Swartz and Snowden, who symbolize the disruptive and dynamic nature of the Internet. The film reveals the emotional bond between Lessig and Swartz, and how it was Swartz (the mentee) that challenged Lessig (the mentor) to engage in the political activism that has led to Lessig's crusade for <a href="Campaign%20finance%20reform%20in%20the%20United%20States">campaign finance reform</a>.
In February 2015, "Killswitch" was invited to screen at the Capitol Visitor's Center in Washington DC by Congressman <a href="Alan%20Grayson">Alan Grayson</a>. The event was held on the eve of the Federal Communications Commission's historic decision on <a href="Net%20Neutrality">Net Neutrality</a>. Lessig, Congressman Grayson, and <a href="Free%20Press%20%28organization%29">Free Press (organization)</a> CEO Craig Aaron spoke about the importance of protecting net neutrality and the free and open Internet.
Congressman Grayson states that Killswitch is "One of the most honest accounts of the battle to control the Internet -- and access to information itself." <a href="Richard%20von%20Busack">Richard von Busack</a> of the <a href="Metro%20Silicon%20Valley">Metro Silicon Valley</a>, writes of "Killswitch", "Some of the most lapidary use of found footage this side of The Atomic Café". Fred Swegles of the <a href="Orange%20County%20Register">Orange County Register</a>, remarks, "Anyone who values unfettered access to online information is apt to be captivated by "Killswitch", a gripping and fast-paced documentary." Kathy Gill of <a href="GeekWire">GeekWire</a> asserts that ""Killswitch" is much more than a dry recitation of technical history. Director Ali Akbarzadeh, producer Jeff Horn, and writer Chris Dollar created a human centered story. A large part of that connection comes from Lessig and his relationship with Swartz."
The Electors Trust.
In December 2016 Lawrence Lessig and <a href="Laurence%20Tribe">Laurence Tribe</a> established <a href="The%20Electors%20Trust">The Electors Trust</a> under the aegis of <a href="Equal%20Citizens">EqualCitizens.US</a> to provide <a href="pro%20bono">pro bono</a> legal counsel as well as a secure communications platform for those of the <a href="List%20of%20United%20States%20presidential%20electors%2C%202016">538 members</a> of the <a href="United%20States%20Electoral%20College">United States Electoral College</a> who are regarding a <a href="faithless%20elector">vote of conscience</a> against <a href="Donald%20Trump">Donald Trump</a> in the <a href="2016%20United%20States%20presidential%20election">presidential election</a>
Lessig hosts the podcast Another Way in conjunction with <a href="The%20Young%20Turks">The Young Turks</a> Network
Money in politics activism.
At the iCommons iSummit 07, Lessig announced that he would stop focusing his attention on copyright and related matters and work on <a href="political%20corruption">political corruption</a> instead, as the result of a transformative conversation with <a href="Aaron%20Swartz">Aaron Swartz</a>, a young internet prodigy whom Lessig met through his work with <a href="Creative%20Commons">Creative Commons</a>. This new work was partially facilitated through his <a href="wiki">wiki</a>, Lessig Wiki, which he has encouraged the public to use to document cases of corruption. Lessig criticized the <a href="Revolving%20door%20%28politics%29">revolving door</a> phenomenon in which legislators and staffers leave office to become <a href="Lobbying%20in%20the%20United%20States">lobbyists</a> and have become beholden to special interests.
In February 2008, a <a href="Facebook">Facebook</a> group formed by law professor <a href="John%20Palfrey">John Palfrey</a> encouraged him to run for Congress from <a href="California%27s%2012th%20congressional%20district">California's 12th congressional district</a>, the seat vacated by the death of Representative <a href="Tom%20Lantos">Tom Lantos</a>. Later that month, after forming an "exploratory project", he decided not to run for the vacant seat.
Rootstrikers.
Despite having decided to forgo running for Congress himself, Lessig remained interested in attempting to change Congress to reduce corruption. To this end, he worked with political consultant <a href="Joe%20Trippi">Joe Trippi</a> to launch a web based project called "<a href="Change%20Congress">Change Congress</a>". In a press conference on March 20, 2008, Lessig explained that he hoped the Change Congress website would help provide technological tools voters could use to hold their representatives accountable and reduce the influence of money on politics. He is a board member of <a href="MAPLight.org">MAPLight.org</a>, a nonprofit research group illuminating the connection between money and politics.
<a href="Change%20Congress">Change Congress</a> later became "Fix Congress First", and was finally named <a href="Rootstrikers">Rootstrikers</a>. In November 2011, Lessig announced that Rootstrikers would join forces with <a href="Dylan%20Ratigan">Dylan Ratigan</a>'s "Get Money Out" campaign, under the umbrella of the United Republic organization. Rootstrikers subsequently came under the aegis of <a href="Demand%20Progress">Demand Progress</a>, an organization co-founded by Aaron Swartz.
Article V convention.
In 2010, Lessig began to organize for a national Article V convention. He co-founded "Fix Congress First!" with <a href="Joe%20Trippi">Joe Trippi</a>. In a speech in 2011, Lessig revealed that he was disappointed with Obama's performance in office, criticizing it as a "betrayal", and he criticized the president for using "the (Hillary) Clinton playbook". Lessig has called for state governments to call for a national Article V convention, including by supporting <a href="Wolf-PAC">Wolf-PAC</a>, a national organization attempting to call an Article V convention to address the problem. The convention Lessig supports would be populated by a "random proportional selection of citizens" which he suggested would work effectively. He said "politics is a rare sport where the amateur is better than the professional." He promoted this idea at a September 24–25, 2011, conference he co-chaired with the <a href="Tea%20Party%20Patriots">Tea Party Patriots</a>' national coordinator, in Lessig's October 5, 2011, book, "<a href="Republic%2C%20Lost">Republic, Lost</a>: How Money Corrupts Congress—and a Plan to Stop It," and at the Occupy protest in Washington, DC. Reporter <a href="Dan%20Froomkin">Dan Froomkin</a> said the book offers a manifesto for the <a href="Occupy%20Wall%20Street">Occupy Wall Street</a> protestors, focusing on the core problem of corruption in both political parties and their elections. An Article V convention does not dictate a solution, but Lessig would support a constitutional amendment that would allow legislatures to limit political contributions from non-citizens, including corporations, anonymous organizations, and foreign nationals, and he also supports <a href="Public%20financing%20of%20campaigns">public campaign financing</a> and <a href="Electoral%20College%20%28United%20States%29">electoral college</a> reform to establish the <a href="one%20person%2C%20one%20vote">one person, one vote</a> principle.
New Hampshire Rebellion.
The <a href="Coalition%20for%20Open%20Democracy">New Hampshire Rebellion</a> is a walk to raise awareness about corruption in politics. The event began in 2014 with a 185-mile march in New Hampshire. In its second year the walk expanded to include other locations in New Hampshire.
From January 11 to 24, 2014, Lessig and many others, like New York activist <a href="Jeff%20Kurzon">Jeff Kurzon</a>, marched from <a href="Dixville%20Notch%2C%20New%20Hampshire">Dixville Notch, New Hampshire</a> to Nashua (a 185-mile march) to promote the idea of tackling "the systemic corruption in Washington". Lessig chose this language over the related term "campaign finance reform," commenting that "Saying we need campaign finance reform is like referring to an alcoholic as someone who has a liquid intake problem." The walk was to continue the work of NH native <a href="Doris%20Haddock">Doris "Granny D" Haddock</a>, and in honor of deceased activist <a href="Aaron%20Swartz">Aaron Swartz</a>. The New Hampshire Rebellion marched 16 miles from Hampton to New Castle on the New Hampshire Seacoast. The initial location was also chosen because of its important and visible role in the quadrennial "New Hampshire primaries", the traditional first primary of the presidential election.
2016 presidential candidacy.
Lessig announced the launch of his long shot presidential campaign on September 6, 2015.
On August 11, 2015, Lessig announced that he had launched an exploratory campaign for the purpose of exploring his prospects of winning the <a href="Democratic%20Party%20%28United%20States%29">Democratic Party</a>'s <a href="Democratic%20Party%20presidential%20primaries%2C%202016">nomination</a> for <a href="president%20of%20the%20United%20States">president of the United States</a> in the <a href="2016%20United%20States%20presidential%20election">2016 election</a>. Lessig pledged to seek the nomination if he raised $1 million by <a href="Labor%20Day">Labor Day</a> 2015. The announcement was widely reported in national media outlets, and was timed to coincide with a media blitz by the Lessig 2016 Campaign. Lessig was interviewed in "<a href="The%20New%20York%20Times">The New York Times</a>" and <a href="Bloomberg%20L.P.">Bloomberg</a>. Campaign messages and Lessig's electoral finance reform positions were circulated widely on social media. His campaign was focused on a single issue: <a href="The%20Citizen%20Equality%20Act">The Citizen Equality Act</a>, a proposal that couples <a href="Campaign%20finance%20reform%20in%20the%20United%20States">campaign finance reform</a> with other laws aimed at curbing <a href="Gerrymandering%20in%20the%20United%20States">gerrymandering</a> and ensuring <a href="Voter%20suppression%20in%20the%20United%20States">voting access</a>. As an expression of his commitment to the proposal, Lessig initially promised to resign once the Citizen Equality Act became law and turn the presidency over to his vice president, who would then serve out the remainder of the term as a typical American president and act on a variety of issues. In October 2015, Lessig abandoned his automatic resignation plan and adopted a full policy platform for the presidency, though he did retain the passage of the Citizen Equality Act as his primary legislative objective.
Lessig made a single campaign stop in Iowa, with an eye toward the first-in-the-nation precinct caucuses: at Dordt College, in Sioux Center, in late October. He announced the end of his campaign on November 2, 2015.
Electoral College reform.
In 2017, Lessig announced a movement to challenge the <a href="Plurality%20voting%20system">winner-take-all</a> <a href="Electoral%20College%20%28United%20States%29">Electoral College</a> vote allocation in the various states, called "<a href="Equal%20Citizens%23Equal%20Votes">Equal Votes</a>". Lessig was also a counsel for electors in the Supreme Court case "<a href="Chiafalo%20v.%20Washington">Chiafalo v. Washington</a>" where the court decided states could force electors to follow the state's popular vote.
Awards and honors.
In 2002, Lessig received the <a href="Award%20for%20the%20Advancement%20of%20Free%20Software">Award for the Advancement of Free Software</a> from the <a href="Free%20Software%20Foundation">Free Software Foundation</a> (FSF). He also received the <a href="Scientific%20American">Scientific American 50 Award</a> for having "argued against interpretations of copyright that could stifle innovation and discourse online." Then, in 2006, Lessig was elected to the <a href="American%20Academy%20of%20Arts%20and%20Sciences">American Academy of Arts and Sciences</a>.
In 2011, Lessig was named to the Fastcase 50, "honoring the law's smartest, most courageous innovators, techies, visionaries, and leaders." Lessig was awarded honorary doctorates by the Faculty of Social Sciences at <a href="Lund%20University">Lund University</a>, Sweden in 2013 and by the <a href="Universit%C3%A9%20catholique%20de%20Louvain">Université catholique de Louvain</a> in 2014. Lessig received the <a href="2014%20Webby%20Awards">2014 Webby Lifetime Achievement</a> award for co-founding Creative Commons and defending net neutrality and the <a href="free%20and%20open%20software">free and open software</a> movement.
Personal life.
Lessig was born in <a href="Rapid%20City%2C%20South%20Dakota">Rapid City, South Dakota</a>, the son of Patricia (West), who sold real estate, and Lester L. "Jack" Lessig, an engineer. He grew up in <a href="Williamsport%2C%20Pennsylvania">Williamsport, Pennsylvania</a>.
In May 2005, it was revealed that Lessig had experienced <a href="sexual%20abuse">sexual abuse</a> by the director at the <a href="American%20Boychoir%20School">American Boychoir School</a>, which he had attended as an adolescent. Lessig reached a settlement with the school in the past, under confidential terms. He revealed his experiences in the course of representing another student victim, John Hardwicke, in court. In August 2006, he succeeded in persuading the <a href="New%20Jersey%20Supreme%20Court">New Jersey Supreme Court</a> to radically restrict the scope of immunity, which had protected nonprofits that failed to prevent sexual abuse from legal liability.
Lessig is married to Bettina Neuefeind, a German-born Harvard University colleague. The two married in 1999. He and Neuefeind have three children: Willem, who is a Crypto-Miner, Coffy, who is a streamer, and Tess.
Defamation lawsuit against the "New York Times".
In 2019, during the criminal investigation of <a href="Jeffrey%20Epstein">Jeffrey Epstein</a>, it was discovered that the <a href="MIT%20Media%20Lab">MIT Media Lab</a>, under former president <a href="Joichi%20Ito">Joichi Ito</a>, had accepted secret donations from Epstein after Epstein had been convicted on criminal charges. Ito eventually resigned as president following this discovery. After making supportive comments to Ito, Lessig wrote a <a href="Medium%20%28website%29">Medium</a> post in September 2019 to explain his stance. In his post, Lessig acknowledged that universities should not take donations from convicted criminals like Epstein who had become wealthy through actions unrelated to their criminal convictions; however, if such donations were to be accepted, it was better to take them secretly rather than publicly connect the university to the criminal. Lessig's essay drew criticism, and about a week later, <a href="Nellie%20Bowles">Nellie Bowles</a> of "<a href="The%20New%20York%20Times">The New York Times</a>" had an interview with Lessig in which he reiterated his stance related to such donations broadly. The article used the headline "A Harvard Professor Doubles Down: If You Take Epstein’s Money, Do It in Secret", which Lessig confirmed was based on a statement he had made to the "Times". Lessig took issue with the headline overlooking his argument that MIT should not accept such donations in the first place and also criticized the first two lines of the article which read "It is hard to defend soliciting donations from the convicted sex offender Jeffrey Epstein. But Lawrence Lessig, a Harvard Law professor, has been trying." He subsequently accused the "Times" of writing <a href="clickbait">clickbait</a> with the headline crafted to defame him, and stated that the circulation of the article on social media had hurt his reputation.
In January 2020, Lessig filed a defamation lawsuit against the "Times", including writer Bowles, business editor Ellen Pollock, and executive editor Dean Baquet. The "Times" stated they will "vigorously" defend against Lessig's claim, and believe that what they had published was accurate and had been reviewed by senior editors following Lessig's initial complaints.
In April 2020, the "New York Times" changed its original headline to read: "What Are the Ethics of Taking Tainted Funds? A conversation with Lawrence Lessig about Jeffrey Epstein, M.I.T. and reputation laundering." Lessig reported he subsequently withdrew his defamation lawsuit.
